values: Do you ever wonder about all the pictures you must be in, that you don't know about? All those times when you're someplace and see other people who, like you, are taking pictures? Every now and then some random stranger in a picture of mine will make me wonder who they are, what they do, what their life is like. One particular woman in Paris was especially captivating; she certainly had the whole je ne sais quoi thing down pat, a hint of a smile playing at the corners of her lips and her hair twisted up into that messy, I'm-not-trying-to-look-sexy-but-am-succeeding-wildly-anyway sort of chignon that Parisian women must be born knowing how to do. Yep, chignon-twisting and scarf-tying, 2 areas where Parisian women may never be bested. A man in Rome had dark Italian skin with eyes as almost painfully blue as a Siberian Husky. What got me started thinking about this? I saw a picture online earlier tonight. It shows the waiting area in the Des Moines airport, and in the background, leaning against a pole, stands a blonde-haired girl wearing jeans and a black jacket. She's pictured from behind, so that's almost all you can tell about her. But she looks just like me, same height (mildly tallish - I'm 5'7"), same weight/body frame, same hair color and length. I wore a black jacket that looks like the one pictured all through the winter and spring, and I'm certainly no stranger to the Des Moines airport. Of course I have no way of ever knowing if that actually IS me in the picture, but it was strange nonetheless, to open a picture and immediately notice a background figure out of some sort of instinctual recognition. Thinking that it might be me in the picture gave me an eerie feeling for absolutely no reason whatsoever, which then made me start thinking about the hundreds (and I don't think it would be a stretch to say possibly even thousands, if you consider all 27 years) of other people's pictures I'm most likely in.

Although it would take a *complete* reversal of my usual politics to ever vote for a Republican president, I will give McCain a few (small) props after reading an article tonight that said that he, during a recent meet & greet at the Iowa State Fair, was ballsy enough to tell a bunch of Iowans that he does not support ethanol subsidies.  As an added bonus, he's said that he would veto the Farm Bill too.

So I like him just a little, or at least dislike him a teensy bit less, now.  We should NOT be subsidizing ethanol production, no sir.  For that matter, we shouldn't be heavily subsidizing corn and soybeans in general, but that'd be a very unpopular opinion for a politician to have.

Sometimes, I really like being an Iowan. Sweet corn season is one of those times! We got a dozen ears of sweet corn with our CSA share this week. We weren't very hungry, so our dinner ended up being several ears of it + lots of green & yellow wax beans sauteed in a little butter and garlic + a sliced heirloom tomato. I also brought a couple small slices of garlic focaccia home from work. That's it, and that's all we needed. There's other leftovers and things if we get hungry later. Eating a dinner that pretty much consisted of nothing but vegetables tonight made me realize how much my tastes have changed since that entry I wrote 3 months ago in which I stated that I don't like vegetables - that I'm a fruit-lover, but have never cared for vegetables. Now, I take that back entirely. I love all sorts of vegetables and I have the CSA to thank for showing me how good they can be when they're grown locally and organically and picked just hours before they're given to you. I particularly love sugar snap peas, carrots, broccoli, green beans, green onions, spinach, bell peppers, corn, sweet potatoes, you name it. It's gotten to the point where if I go a day or two without some serious vegs, I start feeling all icky and craving them, seriously craving them! I was worried at the beginning of the CSA that I'd be given a lot of stuff I wouldn't really know what to do with, or that I didn't like, but that hasn't been an issue at all. So far the only thing that's gone to waste a little thus far has been a teensy amount of pac choi and a bit of cauliflower. But Jeff and I both keep saying to each other how all this seasonal bounty will make this winter one of the most depressing ones ever. You get used to eating this well, and this healthily, and then it all goes away and you're stuck buying Chilean blueberries or some such. You feel guilty for buying produce that's "covered in diesel" and doesn't even taste very good anyway. In other news, our big Europe trip is sneaking right up on us at a quick pace. We leave on September 15. I emailed all the hotels tonight to reconfirm everything. I then wasted a half-hour just browsing through pictures online of Amsterdam, the Swiss Alps, and Tuscany. Hard to believe in no time at all, I'll be getting to see these places in person. I'm very excited! (and a bit stressed - there's still a small amount of planning to do + I need to do a little clothes shopping and make sure we both have comfy shoes for some light hiking. This is the kind of stress I wouldn't mind having for the rest of my life, however!)

So Jeff and I have been sharing the 325i since 2 months ago when we had to turn the Z4 back in when its lease finished.  It hasn't always been easy sharing it, but the idea was to make it until after we get back from our Europe trip in October to buy another one (which would give us from now until then to use that money towards saving for the afore-mentioned trip).  Hell, just the insurance and plates alone for the Z4 was costing $100/mo!

But now, Jeff's 92 year old Grandma has finally decided to stop driving, bless her.  I mean, she's 92 and still insists on mowing her own lawn, raking leaves and picking up sticks, and walking to the grocery store for a loaf of bread every few days.  I admire her; everyone always tries to get her to take it easier, but not to be morbid, that's probably the reason she's still alive and in good health.  But it was time for her to renew her driver's license and she decided she wouldn't renew it after all.  She hardly drove anyway.  Her car is from 1995 and only has 27,000 miles on it, and it's always been garaged.  Knowing that we were down to one car, she offered to sell it to me for $500, which is absolutely a killer deal.  I could probably turn around and sell it for $1500 or more, but I won't of course.  

But it's an Oldsmobile - you know the kind - big, kinda ugly, Granny-ish.  Jeff couldn't believe that I'd want it and he almost turned the offer down without even asking me about it first, which shocked me.  He likes driving nice cars and would be embarassed to drive the Grannymobile, and so assumed that I'd be the same way.  Clearly, even after all these years, he still doesn't entirely know me.  Nice cars are great and all, but to be able to drive something in really good condition and not have any payment on it whatsoever (just cheap plates and liability-only insurance) is fantastic and I don't care how it looks!  I can be a lot more frugal than Jeff is - not that he's a spendthrift or anything.  He keeps telling me if we wanted to, we could afford a better 2nd car again, but I really don't care.  Why spend the money if we don't have to?  (Or at least for now, anyway... maybe after the trip, we'll reconsider.)  In the meantime, I'm reeeediculously excited about not having to share one car anymore, but without having a 2nd car payment.

Yay!

A few of my favorite things... Pics behind cut: How often do you find strawberries that are this red all the way through? (And this pic doesn't even do them justice!) Answer: not often! They're too fragile to be transported easily - they were organic berries from our CSA and were some of the best I've had besides the ones in France. I love June! How much do I love homemade pasta? A lot! But I love my Kitchenaid mixer with its pasta attachments even more because it makes homemade pasta a possibility for weeknight dinners. It only took 30 minutes of work to make the dough, roll out the pasta sheets, and get them all cut into fettuccine noodles! The "sauce" was just butter, parmesan, and nutmeg.

Oh my God am I tired.  And there's more family stuff going on tomorrow. (Luke's SO cute and sweet, but I don't feel like writing any more about the fam for now.) I slept quite fitfully last night, but I have a feeling that won't be a problem tonight.  Last night I couldn't turn my mind off long enough to get drowsy; tonight I think it's already been switched to the "off" position for the past several hours.

This weekend is a little tough for me, in more ways than one.  Tomorrow is Father's Day.  Father's Days always stink, along with my Dad's birthday (Feb 3) each year.  I wrote an entry a couple years ago that pretty much summed everything up - http://tara3056.livejournal.com/2006/06/06/ - but since then, things have only deteriorated to the point where my Dad and I aren't even in contact anymore.  The last time we spoke was nearly 2 years ago.  I did have to send Wally, my Mom's husband, a card though and I need to call him tomorrow as well.  It's not that I mind sending a card or calling - I care for Wally a lot - it's just that it's weird to do the whole Father's Day thing with him because my Mom and him only met and married 7 years ago, after I'd already moved away.  So I've definitely never thought of Wally as my step-Dad, but he's sentimental and I know it means a lot to him that I at least act like I think of him in that way.  He has to have neurosurgery sometime in the next month, and I know it's scaring him and my Mom (me, too).

Ok, off to bed now... fingers crossed for no more mind-racing or icky dreams, just sweet blissful sleep!

I'm really not made to be a morning person.  

The flooding is still crazy.  I feel so fortunate that we haven't been directly impacted by it, but I feel so badly for those who have been.  Jeff's building downtown was evacuated yesterday.  He walked down to Court Avenue and the bridges and said the water level was even higher than he'd thought it'd be.  Other parts of the state are worse off than we are; there's going be millions upon millions of dollars worth of structural damage, not to mention all the crops that have been/will be lost.  We didn't get our CSA box last week because the farmer was literally trapped on the farm.  And the tornado that killed the 4 Boy Scouts ... what a shame (to say the least).  This has been a very dramatic season thus far.

On the bright side, it's looking like a beautiful day - for now.

(Aren't Britishisms fun?)  I went on a total cleaning binge, and have spent the last, oh, 7 hours straight scrubbing and sweeping, dusting and vacuuming, mopping and cleaning all the windows, doing laundry and ironing.  Nuts.  For those who may not know, I have just a *hint* of OCD to my personality.  I keep a pretty clean house anyways, but we've been so busy lately that it was past due for a good cleaning - and the problem is, I can't ever stop with just one thing or one room.  If I sweep, I have to mop.  If I vacuum, I'm itching to dust.  If I windex one mirror, I want to do them all (and tonight, the windows too).  And the same with individual rooms - I can't clean just one room; I have to keep going and going.  Sometimes I am able to stop myself at just doing the upper level and ignoring the family room downstairs until another day.  *sigh*

What's more pathetic is that I seriously get off on having a freshly-cleaned house.  I don't necessarily like the actual process of cleaning it, but when it's all finished, I am a grinning and very satisfied woman.

We got our stimulus check today.  Woo hoo.  Stupid fucking Bush.  But I'll happily stick it in the savings account for the worst of all possible uses - to give it to Europe during our fall trip.

Our first CSA pickup is tomorrow too, so that's exciting.  I'm getting a veg & fruit share, but passed on the herb share.  They're so easy to grow it's silly not to, if you use a lot of fresh herbs in your cooking.  I was happy to find some organic Genovese basil seeds a couple weeks ago.  Apparently Genovese basil is the best for pesto and lots of other things, but it will be a long time before the plants get big enough for me to harvest.  

Jeff's brother Mark and his wife Monica are coming for a visit in a couple weeks and it will be our first time meeting Luke, their 9 month old son... should be interesting.  (Says the woman who formerly disliked kids and wasn't sure if she'd ever want them, but now is curious to see if her biological clock will shift into a higher gear after hanging out with her nephew.)

Ok, off to bed...

Things I like(d): - First and foremost, free internet access provided by a better-than-expected hotel (so, yes, I'm still in CA ... Half Moon Bay now, actually) - Riding the cable cars up and over San Francisco's notoriously steep hills instead of hoofing it everywhere. By Day #2, our leg muscles were pretty sore, but 2 main cable car lines stopped right by our hotel. - Priceline. They hooked us up with a hotel in SF in a great location (Nob Hill) for $100/night (taxes and all). If you know anything about SF prices, you'll know that's a steal. The hotel isn't very well reviewed online, with lots of complaints that the 100-year old building smells "old" or that the rooms are cramped, and so forth. I'm not that picky, and at $100/night, I was pretty pleased overall. The Sonoma hotel was friggin gorgeous, all mission-style, with a soaking tub with a view and separate shower. Yay Priceline. - The weather being over 60 degrees. That's me trying to be positive. Someone out here said it was the coolest Spring they've had in nearly 30 years and it would normally be in the 70s, but instead, the Bay breeze made it downright chilly for most of the time, and haze kind of hung in the air so much that we missed out on some amazing views. - SF (and CA in general I'm guessing) is so damn liberal. I love it. Everywhere you go, people are recycling. People use reusable shopping sacks. Gay people can be out and proud in public. People vote and pass laws here that would never get passed in Iowa. People care about the environment and the sustainability of their food, and they like buying local, seasonal, and organic when possible. Raw milk is sold in supermarkets. This list could go on forever. - Wine tasting... mmm... and more wine-tasting... Yesterday and today were our Napa/Sonoma days and I cannot tell you how fabulous it felt to be sitting on the terrace at Domaine Carneros today with the sun warming my shoulders, looking out over the hilly vineyards below, sipping a flight of wines and nibbling on a cheese plate. - Good food, good food, good food, good food. Scratch all that; make it GREAT food. Transcendent food. Food that falls into the never-forget-until-the-day-I-die category. I must warn anyone reading that I WILL be rambling about food stuff for a minute. I'm admittedly kind of a foodie, but not in a fancy-food-only sense. More like, if it tastes great, I don't care whether it's 50 cents or 50 bucks. I'm more Chowhound than Saveur, if that makes sense. In terms of travel, if we're going someplace that isn't known for having great food, I don't worry about it and just enjoy all the other things a place has to offer (Amsterdam would be one good example of this)... I don't make restaurant reservations, I don't care that much about what we eat. Food becomes the fuel that allows us to enjoy the great museums, or scenery, or whatever. But, if I'm going to a place that IS known for its fabulous food, I definitely take advantage of it and spend a good bit of time planning for that aspect of the trip. I love lingering over a 2 hour long meal at the end of a day. I love the European habit of eating dinner late, and find that sitting across the table and chatting about the day and what we want to do next is so relaxing and luxurious. A cut to be polite... What haven't I liked? - Traffic - San Francisco public transportation. It's confusing and not nearly as well-oiled / efficient as the kind of systems you find in Paris or London. - Those damn SF hills. Ow. - The Golden Gate Bridge creeps me out. There I said it. It's beautiful to be sure, but ever since I saw a show/read more about the many suicide jumpers who jump over the low barrier to the water below, I haven't looked at it the same. It's a little morbid for me. And one lady who wrote an article about the bridge said that it "speaks" to people, that it can tell them to jump, and that just creeped me out more because I just knew if I tried to walk across it, it would start morbidly whispering in my ear too. Don't get me wrong; I'm not depressed at all. I am however very scared of heights and got vertigo even when descending the stairs of Notre Dame and the Pyramid of the Sun outside Mexico City. When I look down over the edge of something, I start getting tunnel vision and something just seems to want to pull me down. So I didn't 'like' the Golden Gate Bridge because I couldn't bring myself to cross it in the first place! - Alcatraz. Kind of overpriced for what we got to see. Gloomy and verrrry cold weather that day too. - Flying. I hate flying. Jeff is always amused to watch me during take-offs, landings, and turbulence. I hold it together outwardly pretty well, but he can read the look in my eyes and feel my fingertips digging into his arm or knee. He's had aerospace engineering classes and knows all about why and how planes fly. He explains it to me, and I'm not stupid, but always in the back of my irrational mind, I breathe a sigh of relief when I'm back on terra firma and think "we just weren't meant to do that!" Of course, we weren't "meant" to drive a car either, really, but fear is not rational. Ok, I'm going to close for now. Honestly I've been internet-deprived for so long (yes, a week is a long time to me; I'm addicted) that this super-long entry is probably just a manifestation of how happy I was to have it back tonight. Gluttony in a different form.

I grilled bison burgers for dinner - it was my first time eating bison, and I have to say I really liked it!  Better than ground beef, definitely.  The healthier aspect is just another bonus.  I'll probably stick with bison only from now on if I'm planning on making burgers, and will probably try it in chili and other recipes that usually call for ground beef.  To me, it tastes a lot like beef, but "beefier" if that makes any sense.  More robust tasting, yet leaner.  Not "gamey" at all.

For me, bison really is the only other red meat besides beef that I like.  I don't care for venison at all (and yes, I've had it several times), and though I'm somewhat of an adventurous eater/wannabe foodie, I absolutely despise lamb (and yes, I've had it prepared verrrry well by a Michelin-starred restaurant and still hate it... except on gyros, but only if mixed with beef and smothered in tzatziki).

I also love rabbit and saw some at our local gourmet market so I'll have to look into recipes.  I'd like to cut back a bit on my beef consumption, but I'm not going to try overly hard.  Technically it would be healthier to not eat so much beef, but it's also somewhat of a moral issue.  It's incredibly easy to find free-range organic chicken these days and bison are always grass-fed and never given any hormones, but finding grass-fed, ethically-raised and slaughtered beef and pork is more difficult.  

Jeff doesn't eat pork (he's missing out!), so I usually don't either unless it's at a restaurant.  He says it's because he grew up here in Iowa and has been around hog lots and has seen the impact they have on the environment/drinking water/etc.  Not to mention they're usually kept in a tiny pen with no exercise and roll around in their own filth.  I see where he's coming from, but I always question why he only refuses pork, not chicken or beef?  (And then I catch myself, well aware that if I push too much, he might think of turning vegetarian on me.)  Chickens and cows are raised in much the same way... I think if he really thought about it, he'd want to quit eating meat altogether.  I don't think he'd be able to because he enjoys having me prepare our (meat-inclusive) meals and I wouldn't know what to do with myself if I were faced with cooking only veggies.  I ... don't like veggies.  There, I said it.

I love spinach and other greens and eat lots of salads.  I like tomatoes and corn and potatoes (but it's arguable how healthy those are), and that's just about it.  Green beans, occasionally.  Carrots, occasionally.  But I hate peas and all types of beans except green beans, and all other veggies are just alright at best.  I'd have an incredibly difficult time giving up meat.  Partially because I think humans were meant, by nature, to eat meat, and partially because I just friggin' love the taste of it.  I get cravings for it.  (Jeff never, ever gets cravings for meat - or strong cravings for anything, really.)  Some people love veggies but don't care for many fruits, and vice versa.  I'm a fruit freak.  I make up for a lack of veggie consumption by eating lots of fruits and supplementing with a multivitamin.  On the weekends, we make fruit smoothies; we usually have some sort of fruit with dinner each night; I eat a cup or two of (thawed) blueberries every single day.  If given the choice, I'd usually take a fruit-based dessert over something heavier (except when the occasional chocolate craving kicks into high gear).  I find apples and grapes pretty boring and don't eat as many of them as other sorts, but generally, never get sick of eating a ton of fruit.

But back to meat and morals.  I like to be an educated consumer and I've seen photos and videos of conditions at farms and slaughterhouses; I've read Fast Food Nation and was pretty disgusted by it.  But if giving up meat is simply NOT an option for me, then I at least try to support ethical/local producers.  If an animal is going to die so I can eat it, I'd at least like to know that, for the time it was alive, it wasn't cooped up in some tiny pen with atrophying muscles, skin sores, and lying in its own excrement.  When I was young, my Dad raised chickens, a few pigs, and some cows.  After being around chickens, eating them really doesn't bother me.  They're little, and dirty, and stupid (no offense to any chickens who may be reading ;)).  Cows and pigs, though... much smarter.  And I think the more intelligent an animal is, the more guilt I feel.

I'd love to hear back from anyone who cares to comment:  Are you a fruit person, veggie-lover, or purely meat-and-potatoes kind of eater?  Do ethical issues ever come into play when choosing which foods you eat?

I don't go out of my way to buy organic fruit, with a couple exceptions, but when given the chance will always choose free-range/organic eggs and chicken, and like to support local suppliers when possible.  I'm also a bit of a stickler over artificial and 'natural' favors (which aren't so natural after all) and don't like consuming a lot of high fructose corn syrup - stuff is evil.  I will purchase and defend real butter, whole milk, heavy cream, full-fat cream cheese, and real sugar until the day I die.

I've had killer insomnia lately and I'm just absolutely dragging right now... can't think of doing the laundry I'd planned to do, can't imagine cooking (frozen leftovers for us tonight).  Just want to sleep.  But yet I know whenever I actually get in bed, I'll just lie there exhausted but unable to sleep nonetheless.

I read a rant by Anthony Bourdain about Rachael Ray, though, and that cracked me up at least:

"Complain all you want. It's like railing against the pounding surf. She only grows stronger and more powerful. Her ear-shattering tones louder and louder. We KNOW she can't cook. She shrewdly tells us so. So...what is she selling us? Really? She's selling us satisfaction, the smug reassurance that mediocrity is quite enough. She's a friendly, familiar face who appears regularly on our screens to tell us that "Even your dumb, lazy ass can cook this!" Wallowing in your own crapulence on your Cheeto-littered couch you watch her and think, "Hell...I could do that. I ain't gonna...but I could -- if I wanted! Now where's my damn jug a Diet Pepsi?" Where the saintly Julia Child sought to raise expectations, to enlighten us, make us better -- teach us -- and in fact, did, Rachael uses her strange and terrible powers to narcotize her public with her hypnotic mantra of Yummo and Evoo and Sammys. "You're doing just fine. You don't even have to chop an onion -- you can buy it already chopped. Aspire to nothing...Just sit there. Have another Triscuit..Sleep...sleep..."

Bwah!  I loves me some Bourdain, though not nearly so much as Gordon Ramsay.  (And for the record, the BBC/UK version of Kitchen Nightmares is so, so, SO much better than the overly-dramatic US version that I never bother watching.  BBC, in general, rocks.)

My Mom, who never buys anything online, made me buy her a weight loss through hypnosis DVD.  Okaaaayyyyyyy.  I guess she hasn't started that yet, but she's on day 3 or 4 of "The Dolly Parton diet" which is also apparently known as the Cabbage Soup diet.  First, I don't get why attaching Dolly Parton's name to a diet would make anyone want to do it.  The woman looks freakish.  Second, just look at this diet...

It starts by making a cabbage/vegetable soup that's amped up with some Lipton Onion Soup packets.  You can eat as much of the soup that you want, on any day.  But other than the soup, you have to follow these guidelines for a week:

DAY 1: Only fruits with the exception of bananas. 

DAY 2: Only vegetables, raw or cooked. This includes baked potato with a LITTLE butter. 

DAY 3: Fruits and vegetables, but no potatoes or bananas. 

DAY 4: Only bananas and skim milk--eat as many as 8 bananas and drink as many as 8 glasses of skim milk. 

DAY 5: Beef, skinless chicken, and/or fish--as much as 20 ounces, total. You can also eat 6 tomatoes. And you must drink 8 glasses of water. Don't forget at least one bowl of soup. 

DAY 6: Beef, skinless chicken, or fish and vegetables. Drink 8 glasses of water and eat at least one bowl of soup. 

DAY 7: Brown rice, vegetables, and unsweetened fruit juice. 

------------

I swear that looks like one of the more crackhead diets I've seen.  Bananas are evil one day and all you eat 3 days later?  And people talk about the "fat-burning" soup like it has magical properties.  I mean, seriously.  If you eat a soup that consists mostly of water and then eat nothing but fruit and veggies, YOU'RE GOING TO LOSE WEIGHT!  It isn't necessarily healthy and it will most likely come back immediately after you stop the diet, but hey, I guess short-term results is what's important??  Mom and I were talking on the phone tonight and she mentioned how hungry she's been... gee, I wonder why??  She claims she only needs to drop a few pounds this week in order to "jump start" her for continuing to eat better and weaning herself off carbs.  Lord, she's bought into the whole carbs-are-evil thing too now?  

I dunno, I mean, personally I think you can and should eat just about anything you want *in moderation* and that carbs are most certainly not evil.  Have you seen the old food pyramid - remember what the bottom "step" of the pyramid was?  The step that formed the largest percentage of your daily diet with 6-11 servings per day?  That's right - carbs.  I tried to explain to her that losing weight is a simple issue of caloric intake.  If you need 1800 calories a day to function and you only eat 1500 a day, you will slowly lose weight (slowly is the key word there), and if you eat over 1800 a day, you will slowly gain it.  Those 1800 (just an example #) calories can come from friggin ice cream and nothing else if you want and you still won't gain weight if you don't exceed 1800 total calories in a day.  You won't be healthy, mind you - over time you'll become a skinny person setting yourself up for heart disease, but you know, still skinny.  Le sigh.

I really hope I never have a serious weight problem because I totally lack the willpower to stick to one of these fad-type diets.  I mean, I'm taking nasty prednisolone and sure enough, it's caused me to gain a few pounds of - presumably - water weight (not to mention my skin isn't as happy as usual), but ain't no way in hell you'll find me knocking back bananas and skim milk next week when I'm no longer taking these nasty pills.

"Tara, I swear I ate a TON of grapes, like a whole bag from the grocery store, and I was still starving that night!"  *slaps forehead*

Have been invited to a wedding near Half Moon Bay, south of San Francisco.  We had been playing with the idea of using our frequent flyer miles for a free trip to Washington DC, and that would have been a particularly cheap trip because in addition to the free flights, the Smithsonian museums and most of the other things we'd want to do are also free + Priceline is great for DC hotels. 

But now I'm glad we haven't made plans for that since this wedding invitation just arrived.  A trip to San Francisco would be much more expensive than DC - we'd still use our miles for the flight, but hotels are insanely expensive in that area (and it isn't as good of a city for Priceline) + the attractions aren't free + a 3-4 day trip was ideal for DC, but we'd need 6-7 for this one + the FOOD!!!!!!

I'm not quite in The French Laundry league (nor could I get reservations if I were!), but you would not be able to get me on the plane back to Iowa without a meal at Chez Panisse Cafe at the very least.  And possibly Bouchon out in Napa.  In fact, I'm thinking this could be a much cooler trip than DC.  The natural beauty of the area is without question, the food is fab, *and* we can be good friends and show up for Corey's big day.  Definitely an interesting idea, and one I'll need to decide on quickly if I want those FF tix!

In browsing the web looking for hints about how to vary the baking time of lasagna when using freshly homemade pasta sheets (which I made, and which was YUM) and whether I had to boil the sheets before layering up the lasagna, I encountered a post in a woman's blog... it answered my lasagna question, but as I glanced over her various pages, I felt more and more squicky and uncomfortable but couldn't resist looking at her "Bring Him Home" page: http://www.happyhousewifery.com/connie/bring-him-home.html

It's a nice, cool fall evening, so it was time for me to pull out the ol' goulash recipe.  Hungarian-style goulash, not American, the latter being some strange staple of yesteryear's housewives that bears no resemblance to the original.  American goulash typically consists of hamburger meat, onions, tomato sauce, and pasta (usually elbow macaroni), and frankly, doesn't taste very good.  Hungarian goulash is a spicier, more flavorful dish that can be either a soup-like texture which you then put over mashed potatoes or noodles, or a hearty stew-like texture, in which case you'd thicken it with diced potatoes that cook along with the meat.  I much prefer the stew version; if you don't, omit the potatoes.

Recipe:  Heat some olive oil in a large pot, dice a large yellow onion (about 2 cups of diced onion), add it to the pot and let it carmelize a bit.  Add 3 cloves of fresh garlic, finely diced, along with 3 TBSP of tomato paste, 2 TBSP balsamic vinegar, 2 tsp dried marjoram, 1/4 tsp dried thyme, 1 bay leaf, 2 cups chicken broth, and most importantly: paprika - 1.5 TBSP of sweet paprika + 1 tsp spicy paprika (you can sub sweet if you don't want it to have heat, or if you like a lot of heat, use less sweet).  Try to find a nice quality paprika - I like Penzeys.  Now, cut around 2 pounds of beef chuck or beef shank into cubes and peel & dice 1 or 1.5 baking potatoes into cubes.  Add the potato and beef cubes, season with salt and pepper, stir it all up and let it cook on medium-low-ish heat (gentle simmer) for at least an hour and a half, and maybe even 2 or more (all depends on how large your cubes are and how tough/tender the meat).  It's done when the meat is tender and the potatoes have disintegrated into the stew, thickening it. Yum.

Note: Some people prefer to brown the beef along with the onion before adding all the liquids.  I suppose it makes for "prettier" beef when it's been browned, but honestly, underneath all that orange-red sauce, you can't see it, nor can you taste any difference (I've tried both).

Enjoy :)

The weather's turning cooler here, and it's nice.  I love this time of year.  I much prefer fall and spring to the extremes of winter and summer, and maybe love fall most of all since it doesn't (usually) rain endlessly like it does in the spring.  On the other hand, the days get longer in spring, which makes me happy, whereas I'm not liking the increasingly shorter days we're having now.

Anyway, a chill is in the air.  I've been crazily running from place to place for a couple of days, and everywhere I go, I see women wearing knee-high boots.  I love knee-high boots, especially if the heel is a stiletto instead of the chunky type.  The ogling won't be great for another few weeks - it's not cold enough yet - but it's another reason why I love fall.

See, in Iowa, we have 4 very definite seasons.  From about December until March-April, we wear layers.  Thick sweaters, wool pants, Smartwool socks, coats, hats, gloves.  And we stay inside an awful lot, hiding from the take-your-breath-away icy wind.  While I hate the winter, it does have its pleasures.  There's the gorgeous snowy days, before all the white snow becomes nasty and gray and dehydrated.  And when spring finally comes, it seems like Spring Fever actually exists here.  Back in the South, we never really had such a change from winter to spring and so didn't feel that rush of happiness and energy it seems like most people here get as soon as the temperature tops 55.  People start running around in shorts and t-shirts at the earliest possible opportunity, when at the same temperature in fall they wouldn't dream of being so scantily clad.  In spring, after a season of covering up as much as possible, it feels positively sensual, though terribly revealing, to bare even your arms.  Bare feet become sexy.  The guys on Iowa State's campus are terribly distracted by the parade of bare skin constantly walking by.  Spring and summer are, to them and to most people, the time when women look their most appealing.

Bah, I say!  For me, it's fall.  To me, it's actually kind of a turn-off to see a girl in a short skirt and tank top.  It's utilitarian when the heat reaches into the 90s, sure, but not sexy.  Give me knee-high boots that show the outline of the leg underneath.  Maybe paired with a pencil skirt hugging the hourglass of waistline and hips, leaving just a 3 or 4 inch gap of bare leg between boots and skirt.  My thoughts, all my attention, will center then on just those lovely few inches.  And don't get me started on tight-fitting turtleneck sweaters or the rosy flush of a woman's cheeks just in from the cold.

I recently took a pregnancy test for the second time ever in my life.  I was 3 days overdue on my cycle, and I'm never overdue, so it was concerning.  Plus, in Salem, right around the time when I should have been ovulating, Jeff and I had a bit of a ... mishap.  Without getting into any squicky details, it was a minor mishap rather than a major one, but still.  Of course, only a few hours after taking the pregnancy test (and seeing a negative result), I got my period.  

Waiting to see whether a pink line would appear or not felt so strange; time slowed down and those minutes felt so long.  I had turned the stick over so I wouldn't be able to see the result until I flipped it over.  I had to take a few deep breaths before flipping it, knowing I'd either be really relieved or really freaked out at what I'd see.  Waiting for (medical) test results is always weird anyhow.  When I had my blood drawn a few months ago to find out my cholesterol, I told them to test me for everything else too since they could run several tests on the same amount of blood... namely Hepatitis A, B, C, and HIV.  During the two week waiting period, I was halfway convinced that my cholesterol numbers would come back high, thanks to the fact that I use only real butter in all my cooking and I don't shy away from cream, or duck confit, etc.  (The #s ended up great)  I was also a bit weirded out about waiting for the Hep and HIV results too, since I'd never been tested for them before.  And while I wasn't concerned about having gotten Hep or HIV from my sexual experience, I got a tattoo 8 years ago.  Tattoos are extrememly safe these days, but hey, you just never know.  Of course, all of those tests came back negative too.  Still, the waiting is weird.

Weirder still is the difference between how I felt taking this pregnancy test versus the last one (years ago).  Last time, I was worried sick and I honestly didn't know what I would do if it were positive.  This time, I was less disturbed.  I'm generally getting used to the idea of having a child and, while I'm not ready yet, I would have made the best of it, probably been scared and nervous but then ultimately happy.  I'd much rather Jeff and I make a conscious, deliberate decision to start trying as opposed to having it be an accident, but I'd have been okay.

If I'm truly honest with myself, 95% of me was completely relieved. 5% of me was slightly disappointed.  

Who am I?!?  For the longest time, I didn't think I'd ever want kids, period.  When Jeff and I got married, I definitely didn't want to get started right away.  We were too young and I would have hated for people to think we'd gotten married so quickly for some reason other than that we were (crazily) in love.  In the years after that, again, we were too young.  In all honesty, we knew each other pretty well before getting married, but we only *really* got to know each other after being married.  And then there have been the rocky times, times when we've been thisclose to bailing out.  Luckily those times have been few, and we got past them and they've made us stronger.  Divorce is horrible no matter the circumstances, but kids change everything, and I'd never want to bring one into the world unless Jeff and I were on rock-solid ground.  Now I feel (for the first time) like there's been a real, lasting change in our relationship and that the things we've struggled with before are truly part of our past.  Not that we won't have issues in the future (anyone who tells you marriage is always easy probably hasn't been married, or at least, hasn't been married for 5+ years), but nothing as truly divisive as before.

So anyway.  I'm not ready yet.  Not yet.  But I actually Tivo'd (and watched) a kid's movie a couple months ago - Nanny McPhee - and enjoyed it.  I don't (usually) do kids movies.  I've since watched others, along with a few animated movies thrown in too.  A couple days ago, I just finished reading the first Harry Potter book, liked it, and plan to read the others.  I'd never normally touch a book like that.  I (usually) hate fantasy-type books and movies.  Even as a kid I liked my books realistic - no Narnia or LoTR for me.  And when I'm out in public, I notice babies and young kids more and they're much cuter to me now.  I've had a few girlfriends over the years that would coo at babies we passed while shopping and exclaim how cute, blah-blah-blah, and I internally rolled my eyes and didn't get it at all.  Now I'm that girl.  WTF?  I don't know what's caused this relatively fast change in me, I'm not acting like myself at all - I always thought the whole biological clock thing wouldn't happen to me, or if it did, I'd be at least 35 before I started hearing it.  But here I am, 26, and the ticking is oh-so-faint, but it's there.  Oh is it there.

Jeff and I often joke about my "food ambitions" - things I'm really curious to try, even if I don't like whatever it is, just to say I tried it.

I've knocked quite a few things off the list lately.  For example, I recently had the extreme pleasure of trying a raw milk taleggio (cheese).  It's illegal here, as are all raw-milk (unpasteurized) cheeses unless aged for 90+ days.  But if you sweet-talk your local cheese shop, you can sometimes score a contraband treasure, and this was that.  Deee-licious and stinky in a good way.  

The lobster I mentioned in my Salem entry was another one.  I very much enjoyed it, though I'm not sure Jeff enjoyed watching me dig out the meat from its tail and claws.  He was sweet enough to remind me that the poor lobster had been alive until just a few minutes prior, when it was killed for my benefit, which made me feel a bit like a cheetah on one of those National Geographic shows that show the cheetah, its face all bloody, ripping into the hollowed-out carcass of its newly-dead prey.  That took my enthusiasm down only a fraction of a percent.

We also tried another infamous cheese recently, a French cheese so stinky that it's been banned from French public transport:  Epoisses.  And yes, it is *that* stinky.  Not just gym-sock stinky.  More like if you took the sweaty-ass socks off of Napoleon's soldiers after they'd been marching hundreds of miles for weeks on end.  In August.  And then stuffed said socks into your mouth.  A veritable explosion of sweat and ass and barnyard and mushrooms.  Mmmmmm, right?  Well, honestly, I didn't so much enjoy it (though, surprisingly, Jeff actually kinda liked it!  Dirty, dirty boy!), but I can say that I've tried it.  It had long been on my "ambitions" list.

Let's see, what else?  Non-homogenized milk rocks my face off.  I hate milk but love this stuff.  It tastes the way milk should taste, the way I imagine it used to taste.  It has the cream on top and you have to shake it really well to get the cream to integrate into the milk before pouring it if you don't want a kinda chunky product, but oh man, is it ever good.  Just a few tablespoons of it in my English Breakfast tea elevate it to a whole new level, not to mention what it does for simple cereal, or *drool* Scharffen Berger hot cocoa.  You seriously don't know what you're missing if you haven't tried their cocoa.  It isn't dutched, and beats every other cocoa I've tried:  3 tablespoons cocoa powder + maybe 2 tablespoons sugar + milk = KA-POW!  My first cup of that was enough to lay me out on the couch for a blissful 15-minute come-down.

I tried dates for the first time recently.  And pepino melon.  And meyer lemons (all you Californians can suck it; they're hard to get around here!).  And finally, organic hardneck garlic (chefshop.com) that is so far beyond the softneck grocery store stuff it's incredible.  I've eaten it raw.  Yum to all.

But perhaps the most revelatory of experiences thus far was true, traditional balsamic vinegar.  Not that crap you get at the grocery store, oh no.  Not even the good stuff you find for $40/bottle.  Oh no.  The *good* stuff, the transcendent stuff, the stuff that costs $100 - $180 per 3oz bottle.  The stuff that you measure out by pipette, and it only takes about 10 drops to coat your entire palette and bring you to food-gasm with a lingering 30-second aftertaste.  You'd never, ever put it on a salad.  Maybe a few drops on a steak, but mostly, you enjoy it on its own.  We tasted a 50 year old silver label from Cavalli and a gold label from Leonardi.  The latter is from Modena and was more acidic than the smoother Cavalli one from Emilia-Romagna, and as a result, I actually preferred the silver label to the gold.  Here's a lot of info on the real stuff, the black gold:  http://www.thenibble.com/reviews/main/oils/about-balsamic-vinegar.asp

Okay, so what's next on my list?  I want to try raw oysters.  I've never had one.  Crazy.  I want to find a few good recipes for rabbit because I've seen our local Gateway Market selling it, and I love rabbit.  And somewhere along the way, I need to keep furthering my appreciation for white wines, because basically, I only really love reds, though I do love champagne.

Things I just cannot get into, even though I've tried them multiple times:  Goat cheese - any kind of goat cheese.  I just hate that "goatiness" that they all have, even the mild ones.  Blech.  Liver pate.  Cheese that smell of ammonia, even faintly - real Brie, Coulommiers...  Bloody-raw meat.  Mango.  Walnuts.  Venison.

And now I'm one of them.  (This is unusual for me, as I don't even care for fish 99% of the time, though I do love shellfish.)  I think I never really fell for sushi before because I'd only had it from one restaurant, Taki, where the flavor of the nori (seaweed wrap) is stronger than it is at Waterfront.

So, Jeff lived!  He went through with skydiving.  We met up with three of his co-workers at his workplace and then drove out to the Winterset airport.  After just a couple minutes of instructions, he got suited up in his harness and boarded the tiny little plane.  I was glad that only two tandem pairs could fit into the plane at once, because it left two of his co-workers on the ground to chat with and distract me from the possibility that Jeff could possibly become a bunch of goo on the ground shortly.  I'm making light of it, but I really did have knots in my stomach when he gave me a little kiss and walked away to the plane.  

Around 20 minutes later, the plane was but a speck in the sky, but we heard the motor slow dramatically and struggled to make out the jumpers.  We thought we saw something, but it was difficult to know for certain where they were until the parachutes opened, which thankfully, they did without needing to pull any reserve chutes (an event which happens fairly frequently, in about 1 of 400 jumps).  I couldn't tell which one was Jeff until he got closer to the ground.  I managed to take some pictures of him in the air and during landing.  The landing was soft.  

Afterwards, Jeff was pretty excited, and kind of unbelieving that he'd just jumped out of a plane at 10,000 feet.  He said the worst part was that the plane didn't have a door, and they were just sitting there in the floor, next to the door, watching the ground get farther and farther away as the plane rose to altitude.  And there's that bizarre moment when he looked out the open door and thought he couldn't possibly be planning on jumping out of it within a few minutes.  But he did, and had around 30 seconds of free-falling at 120mph, then a nice 5-6 minute glide down under the canopy.  All in all, he enjoyed it, and said he'd probably do it again, but wouldn't necessarily seek it out.  For some people, it's apparently the biggest adrenaline high of their life; they become almost addicted to it, and that first jump is somehow life-changing for them.  Not so with Jeff, thank god.  It's just something cool he can put on his "I did that" list.

Saturday was a gorgeous day for jumping, with a clear blue sky and virtually no wind.  Today, it is cool, gray, and rainy.  Fall has most definitely arrived - you can totally tell that chilly air is just around the corner now.  Ah well.  I love fall; it's probably my favorite season - early fall at least.  I don't like late fall, when you suddenly realize that fall is quickly turning to winter and that you have 5 more months of nastiness ahead.  Yuck.  Someday I want to live in a place where cooler weather doesn't account for fully half of the year.

The whole house smells scruptious - we just got done making oatmeal chocolate chip cookies.  Yum!  I've made several batches in the last few weeks, pawning most of them off on Jeff's grateful co-workers, and came up with the receipe that seems to work best:

1 1/2 cups FLOUR or omit salt and baking powder below if you use SELF-RISING FLOUR
1/2 teaspoon SALT
1/2 teaspoon BAKING POWDER  
8 ounces (2 sticks) BUTTER, softened
1 tsp VANILLA
1 cup BROWN SUGAR, packed
1 cup GRANULATED SUGAR
2 large EGGS
3 cups OATS
1 BAG NESTLE TOLLHOUSE CHOCOLATE CHIPS

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees, and line cookie sheets with parchment paper.

2. Whisk flour, salt and baking powder together in a medium bowl.

3. In a separate bowl, by hand or by mixer, beat butter until creamy. Add sugars and beat the mixture until fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in vanilla and the eggs one at a time.

4. Stir dry ingredients into butter-sugar mixture with a wooden spoon or a large rubber spatula. Stir in oats and chocolate chips.

5. Place dough onto parchment-lined cookie sheets by large spoonfuls (about 2 tablespoons each), leaving at least 2 inches between.

6. Bake until cookie edges turn golden brown, 13-15 minutes. Slide cookies (on parchment) onto cooling rack. Let cool, and store in airtight container.

**On a related note, the best vanilla I've EVER found, better than Nielsen-Massey and other "premium" vanillas, is La Vencedora Mexican Vanilla.  I recently bought a 32oz bottle (Yes, I said 32oz!) for $14ish including shipping, from ebay.  It's amazing stuff, not so alcoholic as most vanilla extracts, with a really beautiful aroma.  I highly recommend it - get it if you or anyone you know is a baker!**
